All time

79.48.text:

about e-books, we're not talking about that

long. But that made me

my Kindle
now. And I was thinking the funny thing is,

89.54.text:
in a

109.81.text:
some people in this world I guess. Let me

112.65.text:

115.46.text:
people wear. Some people notice other people

types of

131.39.text:

135.03.text:

139.28.text:

151.23.text:

So that's

153.55.text:
really the point of this talk to kind of think
about

157.29.text:
these questions. Pose some questions about
the book and

158.80.text:
give some thought to what is it about the
Girl with the

161.00.text:
Dragon Tattoo that's so interesting? What's
philosophically significant about it?" On

170.37.text:
the one hand.
I mean, these novels are we might call a typical

174.29.text:
example of
hardboiled crime fiction. They're very much

177.05.text:
like, if
you're a fan of the genre, Mickey Spillane,

180.64.text:
or Raymond Chandler, or Sue Grafton. They're
crime novels, detective novels. But, on the

186.55.text:
other hand,
I think there is something about the Girl

188.45.text:
with the Dragon
Tattoo books. They're fictions, but they're

192.31.text:
based on
very non-fictional issues and themes. We know

196.25.text:
that the original
title -- the Swedish title for the Girl with

199.20.text:
the Dragon
Tattoo -- was Men Who Hate Women. And the

203.22.text:
reason for
this title stems from an actual event that

205.54.text:
had a very
serious effect upon the author, upon Stieg

208.24.text:
Larsson. Time
to read a brief excerpt from a news article.

213.58.text:
It will
give more context for this I think.

216.82.text:
[reading]On that day, 15-year-old Stieg watched
three friends

220.20.text:
rape a girl whose name was Lisbeth, who was
the same

223.60.text:
age as him and someone he knew. Her screams
were

226.22.text:
heart-rending, but he didn't intervene. His
loyalty to

229.61.text:
his friends was too strong. He was too young,
too

232.61.text:
insecure. It was inevitable that he would
realize

235.33.text:
afterwards that he could have acted and possibly
prevented the rape. Haunted by feelings of

240.16.text:
guilt, he
contacted the girl a few days later. He begged

245.39.text:
her to
forgive him for cowardice and passivity. She

248.69.text:
told him
bitterly that she could not accept his explanations.

251.78.text:
"I
will never forgive you, ever," she said.

256.38.text:
So in some ways
the three books -- the books in the series

259.73.text:
-- are meant
to be a survival story about a girl named

263.41.text:
Lisbeth and
it's a story about survival and justice and

266.95.text:
revenge. The
three girl novels also have an uncompromising

272.12.text:
moral
purpose. At the very end of the book, there's

275.59.text:
a very
clear statement when one of the main characters

278.84.text:
says
quote -- when it comes down to it, this story

281.82.text:
is not
primarily about spies and secret government

284.75.text:
agencies,
it's about violence against women and the

289.44.text:
So again, the question is why are these books
so popular.

295.06.text:
And I think I would start with the obvious
which is sex

297.11.text:
and violence. So let's talk about sex and
violence for a

301.70.text:
second. Because that's one of the things -- hallmarks
or markers of

304.17.text:
these kinds of books, popular fiction books.
The message about sexual

308.61.text:
violence against women is painfully clear
if you've read

312.06.text:
the books. Some of the descriptions are brutal.
And one

316.49.text:
of the most provocative chapters in the book
that we

319.67.text:
wrote, the Girl with the Dragon Tattoo and
Philosophy, the

322.96.text:
question is raised what effects does reading
about these kind of books, these

326.21.text:
graphic depictions of sex and violence have
upon us as

330.50.text:
readers? Aristotle is one of our favorite
ancient Greek

336.28.text:
philosophers in the poetics he talks about
the cathartic

339.16.text:
effects that these kind of descriptions have,
these graphic, violent images have -- that

344.55.text:
fear and pity are
the primary undistilled emotions that we might

348.71.text:
feel. But
it puts us in the shoes of these vulnerable

352.18.text:
characters. And in that sense,
I guess the point is, that the Girl with the

354.87.text:
Dragon Tattoo
isn't about senseless violence or pointless

358.62.text:
violence. It
is about, in a larger sense, the social vulnerability

365.51.text:
sexual
physical, political abuse that happens against

369.51.text:
these like dependent people. So there is a
larger

372.30.text:
political message that these thrilling crime
novels are

376.06.text:
supposed to get to. And I think that is one
of the

381.03.text:
things -- that's one of the key things that
makes the

383.36.text:
Girl with the Dragon Tattoo kind of a socially
conscious

385.49.text:
popular fiction. So this idea of social -- I
don't know

389.70.text:
what to call it -- moral consciousness is
one of the

392.42.text:
things we discuss in our book in the Girl
with the Dragon

394.60.text:
Tattoo and Philosophy. There's a lot of interesting
moral

397.98.text:
questions raised along the way about the ethics
of

400.25.text:
information, about revenge, about -- one of
the things I

406.08.text:
think we'd be interested in here at Google
is, certainly, how our

408.85.text:
identity is shaped in an online age. That's
something

411.94.text:
that comes up again and again with characters
who are

415.17.text:
computer hackers. To what extent do we control
the

417.61.text:
identity we have. To what extent is it something
that is kind of shaped by

423.17.text:
outside influences that we never see or hear
about? So

426.42.text:
there's interesting themes here. I think there's
a lot

428.47.text:
of different questions the book series deals
with. And

434.54.text:
you might say that the Girl with the Dragon
Tattoo books

436.32.text:
are popular, I think, because some of the
larger themes of the book

438.89.text:
strike a cord with us. It's a crime novel
but because of

443.29.text:
the author's background, Stieg Larsson was
a journalist, a crime

446.67.text:
reporter. It's meant to be sort of
an exposé, too, an attempt to reveal the

452.20.text:
sort of moral bankruptcy of
these people in power. Throughout the books,

457.16.text:
there's a
certain sense of comeuppance for those people

459.01.text:
who get
away with bad things. And more importantly,

461.85.text:
there's an
examination, especially in the third book,

464.55.text:
the Girl Who
Kicked the Hornet's Nest, the last book in

467.01.text:
the trilogy. It's about how society chooses
to treat people it doesn't understand and

472.79.text:
about how social labels
are applied or misapplied. What happens to

476.89.text:
those
consequences. What happens when certain people

479.61.text:
are
characterized in society and the kind of,

481.86.text:
you know, wrong
consequences -- wrong conclusions that brings

485.25.text:
us to. And
that's the other thing that makes this unique.

489.14.text:
It's a
little different than a crime novel book in

492.03.text:
the sense
that you might wonder who are the bad guys

494.73.text:
in the book?
And I think that's one of the things that

498.19.text:
separates this.
For one thing, there's a long list. The bad

502.19.text:
guys in the book: the doctors are
crooked. The bureaucrats are crooked. The

506.38.text:
journalists
are crooked. The business men are crooked.

509.06.text:
The police and the prosecutors are crooked
and bad. So it's old question, Quis custodiet

515.74.text:
ipsos custodes. Who will watch the
guards. Who watches the watchmen. That kind

520.64.text:
of question
that comes up again and again. Like, that's

522.91.text:
a larger
theme in this book series. When there's an

529.30.text:
interesting
article by 'N Plus One, if anyone reads that

533.14.text:
online magazine, where
the writer talks about how Stieg Larsson is

538.10.text:
discussing the
welfare state in Sweden. The welfare state

541.10.text:
has a certain
amount of complicity in these crimes that

543.47.text:
happen all
throughout these books over like decades of

545.72.text:
what happens
in Sweden and what happens to the characters.

548.57.text:
If you
can't trust the system, who can you trust?

551.23.text:
What are you
supposed to trust? The role of the state is

553.87.text:
supposed to
take care of the individual, as the line of

556.15.text:
thinking goes.
But with the corruption that's going on in

559.94.text:
the books, 'take
care of' takes on a different meaning more

563.00.text:
of like the Mafia
sense how exactly is the government complicit

566.55.text:
in these sort of
things. So anyways, the point is the villains

569.47.text:
of the
book aren't necessarily just the characters,

571.50.text:
there the
institutions, the social structures that kind

573.75.text:
of allow these
crimes happen. I think that's one of the things

577.69.text:
that
makes this book unique. It's not just a mystery

580.23.text:
novel. It's supposed to be a mystery novel
with a more politically minded, politically

584.80.text:
motivated purpose to it.
There's different kinds of bad guys and therefore

589.35.text:
there
have to be different kinds of good guys. So

591.43.text:
it's kind of
significant, the fact that the two main characters

594.23.text:
in the Girl With the Dragon Tattoo are journalists
and a computer hacker whose purpose is to

599.18.text:
bring
information that's hiding out into the public.

604.22.text:
One of
the things I talk about in the book is that

606.81.text:
this kind of writing, like
socially conscious writing, is what Jean-Paul

610.94.text:
Sartre calls
committed literature. Committed literature

614.00.text:
is basically
the -- any writing that was with the intention

617.26.text:
of social
commitment. Any kind of writing that was supposed

619.43.text:
to
advocate or inspire real change in the world.

623.05.text:
And
reading these books, reading the Girl with

624.92.text:
the Dragon
Tattoo books, there is a sense of moral purpose

629.01.text:
that's
not so obvious with detective fiction. I mean,

633.26.text:
for the
one thing let's start with the Girl with the

634.51.text:
Dragon
Tattoo. Like, it's a murder mystery and as

637.69.text:
we see it's about a
lot more than just about a murder mystery

641.19.text:
if you kind of
read the books through the end. At one point,

644.69.text:
I don't
want to spoil the book or the movie which

646.88.text:
is coming out
next week, I think. There's a serial murderer

652.06.text:
who's been
committing crimes throughout the decades.

657.90.text:
One of the
questions is why did this person murder people

661.73.text:
or torture
people after so many years. The answer is

664.72.text:
supposed to make your skin crawl.
The murderer says, "because it's so easy to

671.80.text:
murder people
who disappear that never have these crimes

675.42.text:
brought
today." And I think that says a lot about

678.55.text:
the society
that Stieg Larsson thought he was writing

681.68.text:
about. The
other thing I would bring up is that you know

686.35.text:
like I just
said that kind of emotional skin-crawling

688.83.text:
feeling is
something worth thinking about. Sometimes

693.67.text:
when we're
reading a book -- like, sometimes our heart

696.03.text:
starts to
beat a little faster. Sometimes our palms

698.57.text:
do get
slightly sweaty. These are real physical reactions

703.16.text:
that
happen to, you know, things that don't exactly

707.35.text:
exist. So
this is kind of interesting. We've all had

709.65.text:
this
experience. Like, we're watching a movie or

711.31.text:
reading a book. We
develop real emotional reactions about something

715.75.text:
that
doesn't exist. Like, these characters aren't

718.03.text:
real.
These situations aren't real. In philosophy,

720.90.text:
we call
this the paradox of fiction. How does this

724.29.text:
happen? Why does this happen? We
empathize with certain fictional characters.

728.01.text:
We have like an
emotional connection; an emotional investment

731.48.text:
on our part. We feel fear, pity, happiness.
We

734.99.text:
have these real emotional and psychological
responses to

738.09.text:
fictional events we know aren't actually real.
In

742.23.text:
philosophy, like, you know, again this is
sort of a

744.72.text:
paradox. This is something to think about
because I

746.92.text:
think it's something we've all experienced
and like from a

749.61.text:
logical standpoint it's worth thinking about.
It's worth

751.76.text:
thinking about why do we have real reactions.
Why do we

754.38.text:
care about fictional characters that don't
exist?

759.54.text:
Speaking of characters -- I think without
a doubt one of

762.01.text:
the things that makes the books so popular
are the

764.46.text:
character's in the book specifically Lisbeth
Salander because

769.04.text:
she's so unique. In particular, like, she's
the Girl with

772.33.text:
the Dragon Tattoo. She's this sort of computer-hacking,
ass-kicking, weird, revenge-driven, antisocial,

781.18.text:
loner
person but who's also at the same time emotionally

785.70.text:
socially vulnerable. We empathize with a character
like

789.41.text:
that. Someone who's gotten an extremely raw
deal in her

793.31.text:
life. She's the kind of protagonist we want
to relate

796.21.text:
to. Speaking specifically about the Girl with
the Dragon

803.09.text:
Tattoo, as either book, or a movie or as a
plot, it's a different

808.26.text:
sort of book. Like, at one point it's described
as --

811.77.text:
it's actually a fascinating case. What I believe
is

814.46.text:
known in the trade is a locked room mystery
on the island

817.41.text:
and nothing in the investigation seems to
follow normal

819.78.text:
logic. Every question remains unanswered.
Every clue

822.74.text:
leads to a dead end. So the question is like
one of the

826.48.text:
things I talk about in the book is what kind
of book

829.10.text:
exactly is the Girl with the Dragon Tattoo?
It's a best

832.79.text:
seller. It says best seller right here on
the top of the

835.72.text:
cover. And there's something to that. Like,
what I'm

839.10.text:
interested in is that there's something to
that. Like

841.77.text:
this kind of book. Like, what does a best
seller mean to

843.73.text:
us exactly? The experience of the book -- I
guess the

847.15.text:
way I think about it. This is sort of my English
background.

850.39.text:
Reading a book is something that happens,
it's a transaction that happens between us,

853.85.text:
like a reader reading
words on a page. But the question of what

858.16.text:
kind of book are we reading and how we read
it is sort of shaped by

860.51.text:
things outside of us. I think this is something
worth

864.05.text:
thinking about. There's a lot of cultural
factors that I

869.25.text:
think come into play here. That kind of shape
our

873.37.text:
understanding of what, like, popular fiction
or what a best

875.84.text:
seller is as opposed to, like, literature.
So in that

879.16.text:
sense one of the questions I've been thinking
about this

881.82.text:
a lot. The question of: what does literature
mean to us, exactly? What is

883.99.text:
the difference between, like, a literature,
a popular

886.61.text:
fiction book, genre fiction book and natural
work of

889.38.text:
literature? Is there a distinction to be made?
Does it

892.69.text:
matter? Who makes that decision for us? Like,
for

896.07.text:
example, this is just one book I borrowed
from my library,

898.64.text:
Gravity's Rainbow. Can you judge a book by
its cover? I mean, not really; no.

905.09.text:
Sometimes the cover and the outsides do tell
you

907.52.text:
something. I mean, look at it -- it's huge.
Like, it's

909.76.text:
serious business, right, if it's a big, thick
book like this. I

913.44.text:
mean, obviously no, that's not the whole point.
But on the

915.93.text:
other hand there are different kinds of social
markers.

918.11.text:
If you look at these types of books -- this
is a Penguin

921.09.text:
version of the book. It says literature on
the back

923.60.text:
cover of the book here. That's interesting.
Where

926.00.text:
do these distinctions come from about what
makes a book

928.51.text:
popular fiction. What makes it literature.
What makes it a mystery or a romance

932.66.text:
novel? And the answer is, you know, a number
of things.

936.06.text:
There's no one thing that does this. Book
publishers do

939.03.text:
this when they put labels like this on the
book. Bookstores do

941.59.text:
this when they put the Girl with the Dragon
Tattoo like in

944.08.text:
the mystery section, or the best seller section
instead of

946.27.text:
literature section. We do this when we write
critical

950.09.text:
books on philosophy about these sort of books.
Universities do this. Libraries do this. Book

956.63.text:
reviews
do this. It all contributes to the way that

959.29.text:
we think about
these books whether they're best sellers,

961.63.text:
or novels,
or literature, whatever you want to call them.

964.93.text:
It's
interesting. It's a classic 'chicken or the

968.34.text:
egg' paradox
situation like, "is a work of fiction literature?

972.69.text:
Is
something like this supposed to be literature

975.06.text:
because we
think of it as literature and therefore we

977.48.text:
read it that
way? Or is it something only literature after

979.90.text:
the fact.
We read it and somehow it's decided we treat

985.48.text:
it as
literature now? I mean, speaking very generally

989.92.text:
like one
of the things I think we can say safely is

992.91.text:
there is a
difference between this sort of book, like

995.63.text:
popular fiction. It's a
serial nature of a book. They're books in

998.77.text:
a series.
Like, when you read a book in a series like

1001.34.text:
this, like
Twilight or Harry Potter or the Girl With

1005.05.text:
the Dragon Tattoo books. You're reading them
horizontally. You're reading them quickly

1008.36.text:
but they're
supposed to be page turners. They're supposed

1010.02.text:
to be the
books you want to get to the end and find

1012.23.text:
out what
happens next. So you're reading it this way

1014.64.text:
you're
reading it sequentially. In literature, you're

1016.74.text:
supposed
to be reading more vertically. You don't necessarily

1019.01.text:
read books all the way through to the end.
Works of literature, you're reading for depth.

1024.45.text:
You
might read them over and over again. At the

1029.38.text:
peak of the
Girl with the Dragon Tattoo mania, the New

1031.94.text:
Yorker had a
funny quote which I thought was worth sharing.

1035.86.text:
They
said, "we're not looking at Tolstoy here -- talking

1039.76.text:
about
the style of Larsson's writing." And that's

1042.63.text:
true -- we're
not looking at Tolstoy but so what? We like

1047.71.text:
Larsson novels
because they're good stories; they're enthralling

1050.74.text:
stories
with interesting characters that are compelling.

1056.38.text:
And there's
something else to them, too. I think that

1058.34.text:
something else
is supposed to be this kind of moral seriousness

1060.85.text:
which I
hinted at before. There's an undeniably blunt

1064.29.text:
reality to
the books. In the Girl with the Dragon Tattoo,

1067.33.text:
each
section of the book is prefaced with these

1069.41.text:
very real
statistics. One of them said 40 percent of

1073.28.text:
women in
Sweden had been subjected to violence by a

1076.75.text:
man. So the
stories themselves may not -- may be works

1080.63.text:
of fiction,
but the crimes in which the novels are based

1083.20.text:
are far from
fiction which is the point I want to make.

1085.56.text:
So the question I through out before, why
do we

1089.16.text:
feel the way we do about fiction? A related
question is

1092.67.text:
why do we enjoy reading the fiction that we
do? In some ways

1095.98.text:
the argument that I'm making is a good fiction,
a good

1099.25.text:
mystery novel, is a lot like philosophy. As
much as we

1103.70.text:
enjoy the thrill of reaching the end of the
mystery,

1106.76.text:
philosophy shows us that sometimes it's about
the

1108.43.text:
process; it's about the thinking through of
getting there

1110.60.text:
that is the actual thing. It's not so much
the end goal

1113.68.text:
as it is what we do along the way. That's
what mysteries

1117.09.text:
are. It's the unfolding of bits and pieces
of

1118.97.text:
information that we find so interesting. Lisbeth
Salander

1123.69.text:
says at one point. It makes it sound like
she's a good a philosopher as she was detective.

1129.08.text:
She wasn't actually
interested in the answer. It was the process

1131.84.text:
of the
solution that was the point. There's something

1136.22.text:
philosophically satisfying, I think, about
the plot on the

1138.68.text:
of the detective novel in the sense that search
for

1141.56.text:
answers yields tidy resolution. Like, you
know, we have

1144.59.text:
all our answers set at the end of whatever
it is we're

1148.09.text:
reading. So in a philosophical sense, part
of the

1150.89.text:
consolation that we seek in reading fiction
is this kind

1153.43.text:
of reassuring sense that truth can be found.
When we

1156.56.text:
think about the Girl with the Dragon Tattoo
books,

1158.42.text:
there's questions that kind of propel us to
read these

1160.26.text:
things. The search for truth is really like
the driving

1163.12.text:
thing that motivates us to read these books.
How did Harriet Vanger disappear?

1167.41.text:
Who murdered Dag Svensson and Mia Johansson?
who was behind the big

1171.92.text:
government Zalachenko cover-up? What did all
the evil mean? These

1177.09.text:
are questions that have clear definite answers
by the end

1179.69.text:
of the book series. So unlike the clear resolution
of

1183.14.text:
some works of fiction, our real life experience
-- it's

1186.76.text:
true -- our real life experience with the
truth is never

1189.68.text:
quite so neat and tidy. We never have like
resolutions that are so cut and dried at the

1194.24.text:
end of the
mystery novel that everything wraps up nicely.

1199.22.text:
Alfred Whitehead, one of the philosophers
I talk about in the

1203.81.text:
book is -- there are no -- he says there are
no whole

1206.98.text:
truths. All truths are half truths. I think
that's a

1208.95.text:
good way to think about it. So I want to wrap
up with a

1212.75.text:
couple of thoughts. And feel free to ask any
questions

1215.95.text:
if you have them. When we reflect on the reasons
why we

1219.26.text:
read and want to reread books in general and
why we would want to read the

1223.26.text:
Girl with the Dragon Tattoo, we might consider
the

1225.53.text:
following question. What does reading actually
mean to us? Why read fiction at all? Is reading

1232.38.text:
supposed to be a form of escapism? Do we do
it as a kind

1235.08.text:
of mental break from our boring everyday lives?
Or is there something else? Do we

1240.72.text:
read in order to find engagement in the world
as a way to

1243.29.text:
inform the way that we live our experiences?
So anyways these

1248.27.text:
are just some questions I wanted to pose.
Our hope in

1251.45.text:
writing the Girl with the Dragon Tattoo and
Philosophy is

1253.33.text:
to encourage everyone, fans of the books or
fans of philosophy, to think about these questions.

1257.96.text:
So
I think I'll leave off with that and I'll

1259.95.text:
turn the table
over to Kyle.

1262.25.text:

1265.40.text:
seeing the movie that's coming but how much
of the

1269.00.text:
Philosophy do you think is at risk of being
lost when

1271.02.text:
they turn it into a movie around two hours
long.

1275.26.text:

1279.94.text:
version of the movie? So there are changes
that

1284.31.text:
happen -- I mean, there's always going to
be that problem

1288.78.text:
with sanitizing like, you know, the sort of
books to make

1291.84.text:
it a happy ending sort of thing. So like,
in the Swedish

1296.28.text:
version in the ending of the movie, Lisbeth
has more, like,

1300.72.text:
an active role getting to the bad guy at the
end. There

1305.38.text:
are those sort of things that make it a lot
less

1308.07.text:
ambiguous which is the point of the book.
There's a lot

1310.35.text:
of moral gray area in the Girl with the Dragon
Tattoo. That's the point.

1314.47.text:
There are like good guy characters who do
bad things, like

1317.16.text:
kill people and those sort of things. It is
kinda lost. Like, I do worry about that. I

1321.65.text:
worry about that happy ending syndrome. As
an English

1326.84.text:
major, I was appalled by Pride and Prejudice,
the most recent one. They

1331.55.text:
totally killed the ending. Don't see it. It's
a bad

1334.06.text:
movie. [laughter] They do that. They tend
to do that sort of thing. I do worry about

1338.11.text:
that. But I think
it's always. Hmmm?

1340.93.text:
>>Tyler: Yes, it is for the adventurous. That
probably helps. Yeah, I mean,

1344.83.text:
that's a good question though. I think that
always

1347.19.text:
happens. Personally -- and this brings up
another

1348.99.text:
question which is interesting. Do people tend
to read

1352.36.text:
the books first or movies first? I prefer

1356.23.text:
books first. But there's an argument to be
made that when you

1358.92.text:
watch the movie first you get more out of
the book.

1361.62.text:
You're pleasantly surprised by things you
wouldn't have seen in

1367.56.text: >> Male Presenter: Thank you very much, Tyler.
